author: By Herbert Buchsbaum
title: Images of Light: Christmas Services Penetrate Darkness Around the World
description: Despite the pandemic, Christmas traditions endure, shedding some brightness in a gloomy season.
content: Christmas falls on one of the darkest days of the year, coming soon after winter solstice. This year, it also came during a dark time for humanity amid a worldwide viral pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Téa Kvetenadze
title: New York’s Pandemic Christmas: Muted Cheer, but Some Stick to Traditions
description: Bus terminals and train stations were all but empty and restaurant owners said business was slow. Still, the city’s resilience was evident.
content: There was no Santa Claus at the flagship Macy’s store, no Rockettes dazzling audiences with sky-high kicks at Radio City Music Hall. Broadway stayed dark through what is usually its busiest season, and with tourism severely diminished, there was so much room at New York’s inns that many hotels had to close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: What Happened When Henry Yao Almost Went Bust
description: His customers cherished his small business — and him — more than he ever knew.
content: It was time, perhaps, to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Retries
description: John Guzzetta’s themeless grid rewards persistence.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This John Guzzetta puzzle is an interesting variation on the chunky themeless, because its biggest blocks are vertical. I wager that this makes a difference in the average difficulty of a solve, because most of us scan the across section of a grid completely before hitting the downs, so you’re bound to have a few crosses to help you at that point. I know there are some dedicated down-first solvers; this is the kind of puzzle that makes a good challenge for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Fried Chicken Is Joy
description: Try Nicole Taylor’s recipe, marinated in berry jam, or make a Gruyère puff, a classic pasta dish or a glorious pan of nachos this week.
content: Merry Christmas! Welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, and while some of you may be off from work next week, you’ve still got to eat — and presumably, if you’re reading this, you’ve also got to cook. Even the most devoted home cooks have been tried in this endless year of endless kitchen tasks, as Tejal Rao wrote so eloquently about in The Times, and Helen Rosner in The New Yorker. (Do you read Helen Rosner on food in The New Yorker? You must.) I’ve felt it, too, not so much in the cooking itself, but in the relentless meal planning, and the loading and unloading and reloading of the dishwasher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Adapting to a Holiday Season Stripped of Its Essence
description: Pandemic restrictions mean friends and families will not be gathering this year, but Canadians are coming together in other ways.
content: It always seemed odd that Joni Mitchell’s “River” became a Christmas standard. The music certainly contains bits of “Jingle Bells,” and the opening verses describe holiday activities. But it is fundamentally about a sad longing to escape the pain of heartbreak while evoking a metaphor from her home province, Saskatchewan: “I wish I had a river/I could skate away on.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Answering Mail From Our Listeners
description: Critics and editors at The Times respond to questions about criticism, reading habits, favorite stories and more.
content: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: 8 Things We Hated About New York Until 2020 Happened
description: New Yorkers are world-famous kvetchers. But when we got something real to complain about, we changed our tune.
content: The arrival of the coronavirus in New York City at the end of last winter upended everything we did, thought and talked about. That friend who was always 15 minutes late to everything? Now many of us actually fantasize about sitting in a cramped bar, waiting for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Kristen Wiig Would Have Said Yes to One Line in ‘Wonder Woman 1984’
description: Getting to play Cheetah was even better for the “Saturday Night Live” star, who loves superhero movies: “It was huge on my list of things I wanted to do.”
content: “I want you to know, I dressed up for the interview,” a dryly sarcastic Kristen Wiig said from a computer screen. Clad in a well-worn sweatshirt, she was relating a familiar plight: how a monthslong regimen of video chats and conferences had gradually worn down her efforts to appear presentable on camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Robert Thacker, 102, Dies; Survived Pearl Harbor to Fly in 3 Wars
description: His unarmed bomber was caught in the thick of Japan’s attack. He went on to fly some 80 missions in World War II and to become a record-setting test pilot.
content: Robert Thacker, who found himself caught in the middle of Japan’s surprise attack on Pearl Harbor when he was piloting an unarmed B-17 bomber to Hawaii for refueling, but managed to make a hair-raising landing and went on to a distinguished flying career in war and peace, died on Nov. 25 at his home in San Clemente, Calif. He was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb, Scott Cacciola and Marc Stein
title: An N.B.A. Christmas Gift: LeBron, Steph and Luka in Action
description: With LeBron James, Stephen Curry and Luka Doncic playing, there’s something for everyone. If you haven’t kept up since last season, here’s everything you need to know.
content: Christmas Day isn’t just the most important day of the year for our friends in the North Pole. It’s also a landmark day for the N.B.A., where for decades the league has put its top stars and best teams in matchups against each other for viewers to watch while guzzling egg nog. (The league’s first Christmas Day games came in 1947, when the Baltimore Bullets beat the Chicago Stags, 87-70 at the Baltimore Coliseum.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: ‘Box’ or Gem? A Scramble to Save Asia’s Modernist Buildings
description: Groups across the region are rallying to save buildings that officials consider too new, too ugly or too unimportant to protect from demolition.
content: HONG KONG — When the General Post Office opened on Hong Kong’s waterfront in 1976, a local newspaper predicted that the Modernist-style building would “certainly become as much of a landmark” as its Victorian-era predecessor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Unemployment Aid Set to Lapse Saturday as Trump’s Plans for Relief Bill Remain Unclear
description: At least a temporary lapse in expanded unemployment benefits for millions of Americans is now inevitable because of President Trump’s delay in signing a $900 billion pandemic relief bill.
content: WASHINGTON — Expanded unemployment benefits were set to lapse for millions of struggling Americans on Saturday, a day after President Trump expressed more criticism of a $900 billion pandemic relief bill that was awaiting his signature and would extend them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Kiehart
title: At French Resorts, Skiing Has Become an Uphill Sport
description: The government closed ski lifts, fearing they might spread the coronavirus. The skiers came anyway.
content: CHAMONIX, France — Last Saturday morning, dozens of skiers dotted the slopes above the Alpine hamlet of Le Tour. The cloud-snarled peak of Mont Blanc loomed above the Chamonix valley. The snow conditions were mediocre. The sky was blue. There was only one thing that made the early-season scene atypical: All of the visitors, every last one of them, were skiing up the mountain, not just down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: In One Person, the Story of a Place
description: Since 2002, the Saturday Profile has sought the universal in characters around the world.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Minoru Makihara, Who Ran Mitsubishi After It Stumbled, Dies at 90
description: He steered the company, then the world’s largest, through the troubles of a collapsing economy, and dedicated himself to improving relations with the U.S.
content: TOKYO — Minoru Makihara, who led Mitsubishi — then the world’s largest company — through the doldrums of Japan’s post-bubble era in the 1990s and helped it meet the demands of a globalizing economy, died on Dec. 13 in Tokyo. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Southern California’s Hospitals Are Overwhelmed, and It May Get Worse
description: Each day in California brings a mind-numbing new accounting of the tragedy underway. This week, the state became the first to reach two million virus cases.
content: LOS ANGELES — If this were any other year, members of the Los Angeles Opera would have been singing Christmas carols this week in the wards of Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital, which serves the largely poor and Latino communities of South Los Angeles. Instead, a street choir from Skid Row stepped in with a video to bring holiday cheer to the growing number of dying coronavirus patients and traumatized staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Democrats in Georgia Runoffs Bring in Record Haul
description: The Rev. Raphael G. Warnock and Jon Ossoff each raised more than $100 million, according to campaign filings, signaling Democrats’ optimism heading into the Jan. 5 contests.
content: ATLANTA — The Rev. Raphael G. Warnock and Jon Ossoff, the Democratic challengers in the Senate runoffs in Georgia, have each raised more than $100 million since October — enormous sums that surpassed their Republican opponents by a significant margin and underscored Democrats’ confidence after recent gains the party has made in the state and their hopes that they might capture the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: For a Civil Rights Hero, 90, a New Battle Unfolds on His Childhood Street
description: Before he defended Rosa Parks and became a leading legal force, Fred Gray grew up on an avenue named for Jefferson Davis in Montgomery, Ala. Now a push is underway for a new name for the street: Mr. Gray’s.
content: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — This summer, as Mayor Steven L. Reed of Montgomery mulled over ways to commemorate the 65th anniversary of the city’s bus boycott, he took a critical look at whose legacies had been honored since that protest — and whose, it seemed, had been forgotten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Boston Doctor Reports Serious Allergic Reaction After Getting Moderna’s Covid Vaccine
description: The patient, who has a severe shellfish allergy, recovered quickly with treatment. Until now, reports of severe reactions had been linked to the Pfizer vaccine.
content: A Boston physician said he developed a severe allergic reaction minutes after receiving Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine on Thursday, in the first week of the nationwide rollout for the company’s shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cook Yourself a Merry Christmas
description: Waffles, eggs Benedict, tips for a perfect rib roast: Eat well for the holiday.
content: Good morning. Merry Christmas, if you’re celebrating. Hope you’re getting dim sum if you’re not, a nice spread of Peking duck, some version of spicy big tray chicken. It’s a marvelous day for takeout and relaxation. And even if you can’t get to the movies this year, you can always stream. Try “The Flight Attendant.” That Kaley Cuoco is good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: At Home Readers’ Best of 2020
description: What you watched, read and listened to this year.
content: Welcome, and Merry Christmas to those celebrating the holiday today. Perhaps you’ve been opening presents, perhaps cooking a feast, or caring for or hanging out with those you love. You might be working today, or hunkered down with a book. Hopefully, whatever you’re doing, you’re somewhere warm and safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Ernesto Londoño
title: Turkey and Brazil Say Chinese Vaccine Effective, With Sparse Supporting Data
description: The clinical trial in Turkey was much smaller than those of other major vaccine candidates, making the researchers’ claims for it less certain.
content: Turkish officials announced Thursday that a vaccine from the Chinese company Sinovac has an efficacy rate of 91.25 percent, but the finding was based on preliminary results from a small clinical trial and none of the data was published in a journal or posted online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Fremson
title: In Bethlehem and Jolly and Antlers, an American Christmas
description: Scenes from a holiday season that shone bright in dark times.
content: The roads were icy in Frostburg, Md. In Jolly, Texas, the mood was somber. Still, despite a season filled with challenges at every turn, by the time I got to Snowbird, Utah, it was clear that the holidays were in full swing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: The Loveliest Gift: Friends and Books, All Wrapped Together
description: Long before I worked at The New York Times, my friends and I leaned on the Books section for holiday cheer. We still do.
content: For the past few years, four of my friends and I have taken part in a Secret Santa book swap, turning to The New York Times’s annual 100 Notable Books list for selections. We comb the titles, flagging a few we might like and imagining which ones we would pick for one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Small Donations Aiming to Make a Big Splash
description: Environmental issues may seem too big to tackle, but some smaller foundations have figured out ways to have an impact.
content: Brett Howell, a program manager at Coca-Cola in Atlanta, has found a way to use his small family foundation to take on environmental issues that have a big impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Barber II and Liz Theoharis
title: What Biden and Harris Owe the Poor
description: They must reject the politics of austerity and fulfill their commitment to policies that address human needs.
content: Before he was elected in November, Joe Biden promised that his “theory of change” for reforming the economy would be “ending poverty.” He pledged to champion a $15 minimum wage, affordable health care for all and federal action to address systemic racism. In the midst of an economic crisis, a pandemic and an uprising for racial justice, low-income Americans — Black, white, brown, Asian and Native — voted to overwhelm a reactionary base that President Trump had stoked with lies and fear.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Real Estate Collapse of 2020
description: The pandemic devastated the housing industry this year, but there were a few flickers of life.
content: At the beginning of 2020, the real estate market in New York City was still gaining steam. Sales prices had leveled off, but the rental market was strong. Then the pandemic turned everything upside down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Vaccine Memories of Another Time and Place
description: Many older Americans, shut in during this year’s pandemic, share haunting recollections from the polio era of their childhood.
content: Lizzo’s “Good As Hell” greeted the arrival of Covid-19 vaccines this month at Boston Medical Center, where the scene of dancing health care workers quickly spread on TikTok. Others shared triumphant selfies of their arms post-injection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: How Pop Music Fandom Became Sports, Politics, Religion and All-Out War
description: On social media this year, the stan was ascendant, fueling commercial competition, trolling and other arcane battles. How did we get here?
content: Benjamin Cordero, a high school student from western New York, has a thing for pop divas, but especially Lady Gaga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Brooklyn
title: You Got a Bicycle, Now You Have to Take Care of It
description: Tips from an expert for properly storing your bike and giving it the maintenance it needs in the colder weather. You might even be able to cycle all winter if you dress for the occasion.
content: I first took up cycling in New York City in 2005, and at the time, I had never seen so much interest in biking — until Covid-19 struck. As the coronavirus pandemic has encouraged millions of Americans to rethink how they exercise, entertain themselves and move around their own cities and towns, bicycle sales and repairs have surged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Isabella Kwai
title: U.K. Increasingly Isolated as U.S. Restricts Travel
description: America’s requirement that passengers coming from Britain provide negative coronavirus tests is just the latest woe to strike the country this Christmas period.
content: LONDON — It was one more reminder, delivered before dawn on Christmas morning, that Britain is not only an island nation, but one that finds itself increasingly alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: With Pandemic Raging, London Homeless Shelter in Hotels for Awhile
description: Many homeless people in London will stay in hotels over the Christmas and New Year holidays, if not longer, through funding from charities and the government.
content: LONDON — There were a few places Roland Le felt comfortable sleeping in London: the doorway of shops he knew were closed and a wooded area near the city’s canal. Still, Mr. Le, who became homeless after he lost his job as a cleaner during the pandemic, never quite relaxed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: One Vaccine Side Effect: Global Economic Inequality
description: As Covid inoculations begin, the economic downturn stands to be reversed, but developing countries are at risk of being left behind.
content: LONDON — The end of the pandemic is finally in view. So is rescue from the most traumatic global economic catastrophe since the Great Depression. As Covid vaccines enter the bloodstream, recovery has become reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Stateless, She Became the Face of a Largely Invisible Plight
description: Maha Mamo had no citizenship. Born in Lebanon of Syrian parents, she was ineligible for either nationality. It took her years of perseverance and some lucky breaks to find a homeland — in Brazil.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — The subject was taboo during her childhood in Lebanon, whispered about but never discussed openly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: K.C. Jones, Celtics Standout as Player and Coach, Dies at 88
description: As a defense-minded guard, he played on eight consecutive championship teams. He later found success leading the team from the sidelines.
content: K.C. Jones, the quietly tenacious Hall of Fame guard who played on eight consecutive N.B.A. championship teams with the Boston Celtics and later coached the team to two league titles, died on Friday. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Duke Women’s Basketball Ends Season Early Because of Virus Concerns
description: The team is the first Power Five basketball team to start and stop its season because of the pandemic. The men’s basketball team is expected to continue playing.
content: The women’s basketball program at Duke University will end its season early, the team announced Friday, because of mounting coronavirus concerns. It’s the first Power Five basketball team to start and stop its season because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Columbus Officials Move to Fire Officer in Fatal Shooting of Black Man
description: The police chief said Officer Adam Coy “must be terminated immediately” for not quickly turning on a body camera and not providing aid to the man he shot.
content: Two days after a police officer in Columbus, Ohio, fatally shot a Black man within seconds of encountering him, the mayor and police chief moved to fire that officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elda Cantú
title: Los últimos días de Trump en la Casa Blanca
description: Nacimientos en pandemia, la mejor música clásica y lo más reciente sobre brexit.
content: Es Navidad y, como escribía una lectora ayer, “casi da vergüenza decir felices fiestas”. Así que aquí está tu boletín en español de The New York Times, con algunas de las mejores lecturas para el fin de semana y nuestros mejores deseos para esta temporada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: How Pixar’s ‘Soul’ Animates Jazz
description: A look at the ways filmmakers and musicians collaborated to present an accurate view of players’ artistry.
content: Pixar’s animators have a history of achieving impressive feats, making characters and textures feel more authentic in increasingly complex ways. (That flowing hair! Those landscapes!) But how would they portray jazz?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: ‘Vodka in Your Coffee Cup’: When Pandemic Drinking Goes Too Far
description: Some women are seeking to regain control over their alcohol habits after months of laissez-faire consumption.
content: Martha Duke, who has been sober since Jan. 1, 2018, didn’t set out to become an abstinence guru during the “what does it matter anyway” drinking frenzy of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Delivered on Brexit. It May Not Soothe His Unruly Party.
description: Conservatives are united for now over the British prime minister’s trade deal, but as details emerge, he could face challenges from hard-liners and business groups.
content: LONDON — An “exceptional victory,” the result of “fantastic work” and a deal that “delivered” for the British people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Bess
title: How My Father Escaped Jail for Christmas
description: He got out for good by (almost) dying.
content: My wife and I were getting ready for a Christmas party two years ago when my mother called to tell me that my father was in a coma. She explained the severity of the situation as I watched my wife slip on a black dress she had purchased for the occasion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Beijing Reins In Tech Behemoths It Let Run Free
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 25, 2020.
content: “In Chinese culture, if you are a rich guy and you have very strong economic power and social influence, then you are politically dangerous and you need to keep a very low profile to be safe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: Russians Are Believed to Have Used Microsoft Resellers in Cyberattacks
description: Evidence from the security firm CrowdStrike suggests that companies that sell software on behalf of Microsoft were used to break into Microsoft’s Office 365 customers.
content: As the United States comes to grips with a far-reaching Russian cyberattack on federal agencies, private corporations and the nation’s infrastructure, new evidence has emerged that the hackers hunted their victims through multiple channels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie McGee, Rick Rojas, Lucy Tompkins and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A Warning, Then a Blast: Nashville Explosion Was Deliberate, Police Say
description: An explosion linked to a vehicle sent debris and shattered glass into the streets, and injured three people.
content: NASHVILLE — First came the warning, then came the blast, shattering the Christmas morning silence in the heart of the city’s tourist district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Selinger
title: Ending 2020 With a Sweet Bit of Release
description: The hot chocolate bomb is a tasty metaphor for a pent-up year.
content: After months upon months of palliative food trends — baking sourdough bread, swirling up cups of Dalgona coffee, cutting into deceptive cakes — 2020 is ending not with a whimper but a bang, in the form of a hot chocolate bomb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: How a Young Chess Phenom Spends His Sundays
description: Between studying moves with tutors in India and New York, Oliver Boydell has homework (with video game breaks, of course).
content: The problem with contemporary chess, said Oliver Boydell, who has won titles at the city, state and national levels, is that it has become too “positional,” without the mistakes and dazzling reversals of past chess eras. It is just not that much fun to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: A Perfect Score … or Half of One
description: Erik Agard collaborates with Wendy L. Brandes, who makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — We’ve been floating along this week — solving some gloriously happy debuts — and this is another one, at least for one of the constructors. Wendy L. Brandes makes her New York Times Crossword debut in a challenging Friday collaboration with Erik Agard, who now serves as the editor of the USA Today crossword.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Nancye Radmin, Pioneer of Plus-Size Fashion, Is Dead at 82
description: The Forgotten Woman boutique, which she opened in 1977, spoke directly to the nascent idea of body acceptance. It soon became a chain.
content: Nancye Radmin, a pioneer of plus-size fashion who for two decades ran an upscale chain of stores, the Forgotten Woman, that served a group of women who had otherwise been overlooked by high fashion, died on Dec. 8 at her home in Lakeland, Fla. She was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russian Police Arrest a Top Navalny Ally
description: The police detained Lyubov Sobol amid a crackdown on activists seeking to draw attention to the nerve-agent poisoning of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny.
content: MOSCOW — The police on Friday arrested a top ally and two employees of Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader who over the summer narrowly survived a nerve-agent poisoning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Brexit Deal Done, Britain Now Scrambles to See How It Will Work
description: Britain is finally departing from the European Union, but its formal exit is only the beginning of a high-stakes experiment to unstitch commercial relations across an integrated continent.
content: LONDON — For weary Brexit negotiators on both sides of the English Channel, a Christmas Eve trade agreement sealed 11 months of painstaking deliberations over Britain’s departure from the European Union, encompassing details as arcane as what species of fish could be caught by each side’s boats in British waters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russell Goldman and Isabella Kwai
title: U.S. Will Require a Negative Coronavirus Test for All Travelers From U.K.
description: The new rule, which takes effect on Monday, will apply to Americans as well as foreign nationals.
content: The United States will require all airline passengers arriving from Britain to test negative for the coronavirus within 72 hours of their departure, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Marc Santora
title: Pope Francis Makes Christmas Appeal for Nations to Share Vaccines
description: The pope made his remarks from inside the Vatican instead of before large crowds on St. Peter’s Square, as Christians around the world scaled back or reimagined Christmas traditions.
content: ROME — Pope Francis on Friday called on world leaders, businesses and international organizations to help ensure that the most vulnerable and needy have access to newly developed coronavirus vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenn Shapland
title: Butter, Sugar and a Tablespoon of Grief
description: At the darkest time of year, we bake our pain and loss into something to pass to others when it becomes too much to carry.
content: For my mom, the weeks before Christmas exist solely for baking cookies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: 25 Stories for December 25th
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Every December, media organizations publish lists of the year’s “most read” stories (and you’ll see The Times’s list in a newsletter next week). But today — on Christmas — we’re going to do something different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Ali Watkins
title: Police Officer Is Shot in Brooklyn, but Vest Stops the Bullet
description: The 27-year-old officer, who had responded to a call about domestic violence, was “in a little pain” but “extremely good spirits” at a Brooklyn hospital, the police commissioner said.
content: A New York City police officer responding to a call about domestic violence was shot in the back Thursday night, but his vest stopped the bullet and he left a Brooklyn hospital on Friday, police officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Etan Smallman
title: David Attenborough Still Has Hope for Our Future
description: At 94, the beloved British naturalist remains curious and optimistic. He talked about his new docu-series, “A Perfect Planet,” and why the coronavirus may prove to have some positive consequences.
content: LONDON — Take away the state-of-the-art drones and the gyro-stabilized 4K cameras from the BBC’s latest blue-chip natural history series, “A Perfect Planet.” Strip out the luscious score and the stunning close-ups of nature at its most intimate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: ‘Stay Alive and Survive’: Ski Resorts Brace for a Pandemic Season
description: Many have put capacity restrictions in place, even as new lockdowns may spook visitors.
content: OLYMPIC VALLEY, Calif. — A trickle of skiers recently zigzagged down the slopes at the Squaw Valley Ski Resort. Couples and families wandered through the resort’s village, which was decorated with golden Christmas lights and frosted with snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Toby Bilanow
title: Weekly Health Quiz: Body Fat, Pulse Oximeters and a New Strain of Coronavirus
description: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Weekender
description: A finger-food countdown to 2021. The rise and fall of the video game Cyberpunk 2077. A sanctuary for gibbons in Thailand. George Clooney on his new film. And more.
content: A finger-food countdown to 2021. The rise and fall of the video game Cyberpunk 2077. A sanctuary for gibbons in Thailand. George Clooney on his new film. And more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Explosion That Appears ‘Intentional’ Rattles Downtown Nashville
description: An explosion injured three people, damaged buildings and forced evacuations in downtown Nashville on Christmas morning. The authorities said they believed it was intentional and caused when a parked R.V. detonated outside an AT&T building.
content: An explosion injured three people, damaged buildings and forced evacuations in downtown Nashville on Christmas morning. The authorities said they believed it was intentional and caused when a parked R.V. detonated outside an AT&T building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 7 Podcasts to Comfort and Connect
description: If you’re feeling unmoored this holiday season, or just burned out from the past 10 months, these shows can provide a balm.
content: It’s almost time to bid goodbye and good riddance to 2020, one of the worst years most of us have ever lived through. Though the end of the pandemic is in sight, this holiday season remains a lonely, difficult one, with renewed lockdowns keeping many separated from their loved ones, their communities and their festive traditions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 25, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 25, 2020.
content: An article on Wednesday about the decline of the New England Patriots misstated the round in which quarterback Jarrett Stidham was drafted. It was the fourth round, not the sixth.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Generosity to Colleges in Need
description: Readers discuss the importance of gifts from MacKenzie Scott, the former wife of Amazon’s founder, Jeff Bezos.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Leave the Foreign Service to the Pros
description: A former officer seconds an Op-Ed essay’s urging of an end to the “sale” of ambassadorships. Also: Military spending; cheating at West Point.
content: To the Editor:
